p: To date, FAstVs have been detected in stool samples of cats in UK [ 153], Australia [ 9], New Zealand [ 8], Italy [ 157], Hong Kong [ 158], South Korea [ 159], Portugal [ 16], Northeast China [ 154], and the USA [ 17, 156, 160] with prevalence rates ranging from 4.8% to 28.6%. The role of AstV as enteric pathogen in cats still remains unclear, although experimental infection using the FAstV strain Bristol [ 153] in specific pathogenâ€“free (SPF) kittens induced enteritis and viral shedding. Furthermore, natural infection has been described in domestic cats with diarrhea either alone or in mixed infections mainly with FPV [ 7, 153, 154, 157, 159].
